title: Therapeutic Privacy Impact Assessment
description: A comprehensive assessment evaluating how privacy practices affect therapeutic relationships, patient agency, and clinical outcomes in healthcare settings

sections.title: Trust Formation & Therapeutic Alliance
sections.description: Evaluate how privacy practices impact the development and maintenance of trust between patients and healthcare providers

questions.text: How do current privacy practices signal respect for patient boundaries?
questions.guidance: Consider whether privacy practices create visible boundaries, whether patients understand how their information is protected, and whether there are mechanisms for patients to voice concerns

questions.text: Do patients feel safe disclosing sensitive information necessary for diagnosis and treatment?
questions.guidance: Look for evidence of diagnostic gaps, treatment delays, or incomplete histories that may stem from privacy concerns

questions.text: Have there been privacy breaches or near-misses that eroded therapeutic relationships?
questions.guidance: Consider both actual breaches and perceived violations that affected patient confidence

therapeuticLens: Trust is foundational to therapeutic relationships
Privacy practices are visible signals of respect
Breaches have cascading effects beyond information disclosure

sections.title: Patient Agency & Control
sections.description: Assess whether privacy practices empower patients to exercise meaningful control over their narrative and information

questions.text: Do patients have meaningful participation in decisions about information sharing?
questions.guidance: Agency is not blanket secrecy but meaningful control. Evaluate consent processes, information governance discussions, and patient understanding

questions.text: Can patients easily access, correct, or understand their own health information?
questions.guidance: Consider both formal access rights and practical barriers to exercising them

questions.text: Are there processes for patients to express privacy preferences beyond standard consent?
questions.guidance: Describe mechanisms for patients to indicate specific privacy concerns, partial disclosures, or contextual sharing preferences

therapeuticLens: Agency enables autonomy, not just protects it
Control over narrative is control over identity
Participation in governance reduces powerlessness

sections.title: Psychological Safety & Vulnerability
sections.description: Examine whether privacy practices create conditions for the emotional vulnerability necessary in therapeutic contexts

questions.text: Do privacy practices create safe spaces for discussing stigmatized conditions?
questions.guidance: Consider mental health, substance use, sexual health, and other potentially stigmatized areas

questions.text: Are there physical/environmental privacy protections during sensitive conversations?
questions.guidance: Evaluate physical spaces, soundproofing, visual privacy, and conversation locations

questions.text: How do staff behaviors and attitudes reinforce or undermine privacy safety?
questions.guidance: Consider hallway conversations, electronic device usage in public areas, casual information sharing, and respect for closed doors/curtains

therapeuticLens: Vulnerability requires safety
Fear of disclosure creates diagnostic gaps
Privacy is both policy and practice

sections.title: Relational Boundaries & Circle of Care
sections.description: Evaluate how privacy practices define therapeutic boundaries while enabling coordinated care

questions.text: Is the 'circle of care' clearly defined and understood by all parties?
questions.guidance: Consider whether patients know who has access, whether clinicians understand their access rights, and whether there's clarity about information flow

questions.text: Do privacy practices support or hinder interdisciplinary collaboration?
questions.guidance: Evaluate balance between privacy protection and care coordination needs

questions.text: Describe how boundary violations are prevented, detected, and addressed
questions.guidance: Include technical controls, policy enforcement, staff training, and remediation processes

therapeuticLens: Boundaries enable relationships, not restrict them
Clarity reduces ethical distress for clinicians
Circle of care should be visible, not invisible

sections.title: Dignity & Respect Signaling
sections.description: Assess how privacy practices communicate respect for persons and support human dignity

questions.text: Do privacy practices treat patients as persons with rights vs. data subjects?
questions.guidance: Consider language used, consent processes, and whether practices acknowledge individual circumstances

questions.text: Are privacy practices respectful of cultural and individual variations?
questions.guidance: Describe how practices accommodate diverse privacy norms, family structures, communication preferences, and cultural contexts

questions.text: How do privacy practices handle vulnerable populations differently?
questions.guidance: Consider children, elderly, cognitively impaired, non-English speakers, and others requiring tailored approaches

therapeuticLens: Privacy practices signal value of the person
Dignity is experienced through respect for boundaries
One-size-fits-all approaches undermine personhood

sections.title: Clinician Experience & Ethical Distress
sections.description: Examine how privacy requirements impact clinician well-being and therapeutic capacity

questions.text: Do clinicians view privacy as barrier or enabler of therapeutic care?
questions.guidance: Consider whether privacy is seen as bureaucratic burden vs. integral to patient-centered care

questions.text: How often do clinicians experience ethical distress related to privacy conflicts?
questions.guidance: Look for conflicts between privacy rules and perceived patient interests, documentation burdens, or role confusion

questions.text: Are clinicians adequately trained and supported in therapeutic privacy practices?
questions.guidance: Describe training content, ongoing support, ethics consultation availability, and confidence levels

therapeuticLens: Clinician well-being affects therapeutic capacity
Privacy as burden reduces therapeutic effectiveness
Clear frameworks reduce ethical distress

sections.title: Systemic Justice & Equity
sections.description: Evaluate whether privacy practices promote or hinder equitable access and fair treatment

questions.text: Are privacy protections equitably applied across all patient populations?
questions.guidance: Consider whether certain groups receive greater scrutiny, reduced privacy, or differential treatment

questions.text: Do privacy practices inadvertently create barriers to care access?
questions.guidance: Identify whether consent requirements, documentation processes, or information-sharing restrictions prevent or delay care for specific populations

questions.text: How are power imbalances addressed in privacy decision-making?
questions.guidance: Consider institutional power vs. patient agency, clinician authority vs. patient autonomy, and mechanisms for balancing these dynamics

therapeuticLens: Justice requires equal information governance
Privacy protections should not create new inequities
Power imbalances shape privacy experiences

sections.title: Therapeutic Outcomes & Clinical Impact
sections.description: Connect privacy practices to measurable therapeutic and clinical outcomes

questions.text: Can you identify cases where privacy practices improved therapeutic outcomes?
questions.guidance: Provide specific examples where respecting privacy enhanced disclosure, treatment adherence, or patient engagement

questions.text: Can you identify cases where privacy practices hindered therapeutic outcomes?
questions.guidance: Provide specific examples where privacy barriers delayed diagnosis, prevented coordination, or impaired treatment

questions.text: How are privacy-related therapeutic impacts currently measured or monitored?
questions.guidance: Consider existing quality indicators, patient feedback mechanisms, and outcome tracking

therapeuticLens: Privacy is clinical variable affecting outcomes
Therapeutic impact should be measured
Data should inform continuous improvement

scoringGuidance.interpretation: This assessment is not scored numerically. Instead, responses create a holistic picture of therapeutic privacy practices. The goal is insight and improvement, not compliance checking.
nextSteps: Identify anti-therapeutic practices requiring immediate attention
Recognize therapeutic strengths to build upon
Develop action plan addressing key gaps
